sections.heading: CO2
sections.text:
Earth's degassing Carbon cycle Volcanism Mantle petrology Climate assumptions
The role of Earth's CO2 degassing is often confined to the definition of its limited absolute value and considered irrelevant to the global CO2 emission budget. Results reported in literature are contradictory leading to the evidence that the global Earth's CO2 degassing, independently from its absolute value, is virtually unknown. Global estimates are inconsistent with point source volcanic degassing and with the new discovered diffuse degassing sources. In the last twenty years, global Earth's CO2 flux extrapolations increased with the number of measurements from 110 to 937 Mt/yr. Updated addition of CO2 degassing measurements from less than 10% of recognized geological sources equals the mostly agreed global estimates. Careful analysis of data shows evidence of large uncertainties on the estimates of CO2 Earth's degassing, requiring a better understanding of the physical and geological mechanisms behind climate variability and of processes governing the global carbon cycle. Beside model uncertainties and stabilization scenarios, an unknown value of the natural Earth's emissions, with a distinctive C isotopic ratio, leads to inadequate parameterization of unsettled pivotal processes relevant to studies of the global carbon cycle, atmospheric processes, ocean and land uptake, air–sea exchanges, and mantle petrology and dynamics.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Diverse components of the global carbon cycle, interconnected by atmosphere–land–ocean processes govern the fluxes of carbon from one global reservoir to another. The distinction between the different components and their effects at the global scale are difficult and very little known. Uncertainties on carbon fluxes highly affect the evaluation of the anthropogenic perturbation on the “so-called boundless” C cycle analysis, land and ocean sink, ocean C models, atmospheric inversion, and remediation scenarios (e.g., Regnier et al., 2013; Shepherd, 2014).
In the complex carbon fluxes anthropogenic emissions dwarf Earth's CO2 natural degassing. Assuming a natural CO2 emission rate comparable to the anthropogenic one would question most basic assumptions on the global carbon cycle (e.g., Canadell et al., 2007; Gerlach, 2011; Houghton et al., 2010; Khatiwala et al., 2009). However, although Earth's degassing would probably constitute only a few percent of the anthropogenic emissions, its evaluation deserves more than the simple addition of point-source measurements. In the last twenty years, measurements of CO2 fluxes from a very limited number of sources resulted in a total measured CO2 comparable to the most commonly accepted global degassing estimates, highlighting large uncertainties in the evaluation of the Earth's emission budget.
), maria.frezzotti@unimib.it
The debate about Earth's CO2 degassing is often confined to its absolute value with respect to anthropogenic emissions. However, this is a secondary question with respect to the effect of an unknown value of the Earth's emissions on the understanding of the physical and geological processes governing the global carbon cycle. Hereafter, we show that results reported in literature are contradictory leading to the evidence that the Earth's CO2 degassing, independently from its absolute value, is virtually unknown.

sections.heading: 2. Results
sections.text:
We made a comparative analysis of measurements vs extrapolations, vs estimates of the Earth's CO2 degassing. Table 1 reports CO2 Earth's degassing budget from selected measurements in literature inventories (cf., supplementary Table S1). Comparative analysis of measurements through time shows inconsistencies in the resulting extrapolations and estimates. Table 1 shows linear increasing trend of natural CO2 with the number of measurements. From 1970 to 1992, mainly data from sub-aerial volcanoes have been reported. The total degassing budget measured at 10 volcanoes, over the estimated 300– 600 actives ones, was in the range of 38–55 MtCO2/yr (Table 1). Based on the median value of 7 sources, Gerlach (1991) extrapolated the global CO2 degassing of sub-aerial volcanoes to be about 80 Mt/yr (Table 2). In the same years, some degassing of 22–40 MtCO2/yr from sub-aqueous MOR volcanoes has been included for the first time, totaling then a global budget of about 70–150 MtCO2/yr (Table 2).

From1992 to 2012, addition of 28 new sources, includingmoderateto low-degassing volcanoes, lead to a totalmeasured sub-aerial volcanic CO2 of about 120 to 153 Mt/yr, more than the global value extrapolated then years before. From these data, the total CO2measured from38 subaerial volcanoes over 300–600 corresponds to about 0.4% of the anthropogenic emissions, 36 Gt CO2/yr (Friedlingstein et al., 2014).
Mörner and Etiope (2002) and Burton et al. (2013) raised the global extrapolations of the sub-aerial volcanic degassing to 250 and 540 MtCO2/yr, respectively. This increases the previous estimates by a factor of 3 and a factor of 7, respectively. (Table 2). The resulting Earth's volcanic CO2 budgets, including subaqueous volcanic emissions, are 300 Mt/yr by Mörner and Etiope (2002), and 637 Mt/yr by Burton et al. (2013) (Table 2). Independent global estimates of sub-aerial and sub-aqueous volcanic CO2 degassing, based on geochemical data (i.e, CO2/3He in magmas; Table 2) by Marty and Tolstikhin (1998),
suggested 367 MtCO2/yr. This Earth's volcanic degassing budget equals the value of 367 MtCO2/yr (or 100 MtC/yr) reported in the 2013 Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change Fifth Assessment Report (IPCC, 2013).
Although most quoted Earth's CO2 emission estimates report only volcanic degassing, diffuse soil CO2 degassing from new sources, including the escape of gases from the upper mantle, from carbonate bearing rocks in the crust, fromhydrocarbon reservoirs in sedimentary beds and the degassing from surface deposits and surface processes has also been recognized (Tables 1, S1 and 2). Starting from the 1990s, newmeasurements of soil emissions and of lithospheric degassing over large tectonically active areas have been reported (Kerrick, 2001; e.g., “nonvolcanic” CO2), upgrading the total measured Earth's CO2 fluxes to about 236–298 Mt/yr. While these measurements are relatively recent, results in Table 1 show that the total amounts of volcanic and non-
volcanic CO2 degassing measured up to date are comparable. According to Mörner and Etiope (2002), the non-volcanic Earth's emission budget would reach 300 MtCO2/yr (Table 2). Recent extrapolations by Burton et al. (2013) indicate then a total Earth's degassing of 937 MtCO2/yr, as compared to the original value of 110 MtCO2/yr (7), and to the presently considered value of 367 MtCO2/yr (IPCC, 2013).

sections.heading: 3. Discussion
sections.text:
One of the main problems in current evaluations of the natural Earth's CO2 degassing is the lack of systematic and homogeneously distributed measurements. This actually prevents an accurate quantification of the natural source emissions, and makes the statistical extrapolation of measurements, based on a limited number of sources, highly uncertain. It is noteworthy that the present-day Earth's contribution to the global CO2 budget has been focused on the measurement of point-sources sub-aerial volcanic degassing, originally finalized to volcanic-risk assessment in the most populated areas of the world, and on spread data of diffuse volcanic and non-volcanic escape of CO2 from the Earth's surface. Moreover, the CO2 degassing rates from single volcanoes can be highly variable, differing by one or two orders of magnitude. A good example to illustrate the fluctuations of volcanic degassing is Mt. Etna in Italy, which was accounted to produce much more carbon dioxide than other volcanoes worldwide. However, degassing rates of Mt. Etna have varied from 25.5 Mt/yr, as measured in the 90s, to 4–13 Mt/yr, measured by the same author 10 years later (Allard et al., 1991; Allard, 1998; Table S1), depending on the eruptive activity. Gerlach (1991) reportedMt. Etna as a “point-source singularity”, contributing alone to about one third of the global CO2 emissions by sub-aerial volcanism. More recently, the increase of measurements has shown other permanent high-degassing volcanoes (i.e., Nyariagongo, Popocaptel, etc; cf., Burton et al., 2013), though the mechanisms of such CO2 enrichment in magmas are still debated (Allard et al., 1997; Frezzotti et al., 2009; Kerrick, 2001).
Reliable long-term records of CO2 degassing do not exist for most volcanoes, and the estimated time series fluxes imply extrapolation of data from different and often indirect measurements (Kern et al., 2012; Oppenheimer et al., 2011), which include propagation of errors from each measured variable. In addition, extensive surface gasgeochemical measurements have recently proved the existence of geological diffuse background CO2 emissions over large tectonically active areas of our planet (Chiodini et al., 2005). The evenmore difficult sampling, areal identification, and extrapolation to the global scale make the non-volcanic CO2 degassing largely unconstrained, and usually neglected in most used global estimates (cf., Marty and Tolstikhin, 1998).
The comparison between measured sources and global extrapolations and estimates shows some inconsistencies. Fig. 1 resumes data of Tables 1 and 2. Fig. 1a reports the time series of measured subaerial volcanic CO2 emissions (red squares), of measured diffuse soil CO2 emissions (green triangles), and of total measured volcanic plus diffuse CO2 emissions (blue dots). Yellow diamonds report commonly accepted global Earth's CO2 emission estimates (cf., Table 2). Results show a linear increasing trend in time of sub-aerial volcanic degassing with the number of measurements. On the same graphic, diffuse soil degassing shows a quasi-exponential increasewith the number of measurements. The resulting quasi-exponential increasing of total volcanic and diffuse degassing leads to a value of the Earth's CO2 fluxesmeasured up to date on a small number of sources comparable to the most commonly accepted estimates for the total Earth's CO2 degassing (yellow dots). Noteworthy, the isolated blue diamond reporting the CO2 degassing measurement of Mt. Etna, represents about 19% of the total volcanic degassing measured to date, and 7% of the total Earth's mostly accepted degassing estimates of 367 MtCO2/yr (IPCC, 2013).
Fig. 1b shows the same time series for the global extrapolations (green dots) and estimates (red squares) of the Earth's CO2 degassing,
as compared to the total measured values (blue diamonds). Consistently with the number of measurements, the extrapolations show a quite linear increase in time, while the computational estimates, involving mass flux of volcanic material, seem to be tighter to constant values. Results show that in a range of about 20 years, the measured natural Earth's CO2 degassing has increased by a factor of 6 and the extrapolated one by a factor of 8. At present, the total Earth's extrapolated CO2 budget is only three times larger than the value measured from about 50 sub-aerial volcanic and diffuse sources (937 MtCO2/yr, vs 267 MtCO2/yr). Moreover, it has to be noted that extrapolations also include about 10% of sub-aqueous volcanic CO2 emissions. The value of 10% of subaqueous volcanic emissions seems a bit low, considering that about 80% of active volcanoes are under the sea (Encyclopedia of Volcanoes, 2000).
To further detail those results, Fig. 2 shows the comparison between sub-aerial volcanic (Fig. 2a) and diffuse soil CO2 degassing (Fig. 2b) extrapolations, estimates and measurements. In Fig. 2a results show that the sumof 38 sub-aerial volcanic emissions (red bars), representing less than 10% of the total active volcanoes on Earth's, is from25 to 54% of the recent global extrapolations of Burton et al. (2013), 540 MtCO2/yr, and of Mörner and Etiope (2002) 250 MtCO2/yr, respectively (blue bars).
Similarly, in Fig. 2b, a total mean value of 130 MtCO2/yr of the nonvolcanic diffuse degassing resulting from only 16 measurements areas corresponds to about 43% of the global diffuse degassing budget extrapolated by the same authors (300 MtCO2/yr). The isolated green point (Fig. 2b) shows the first reported measurements for the diffuse soil CO2 degassing from Himalaya mountains (Becker et al., 2008), totaling 23% of the soil degassing measured up to date and 10% of the global extrapolations. More critically, Gambardella et al. (2004), as a result of more than a decade of measurements, has proved CO2 diffuse soil degassing in Central Italy, partially from mantle origin, in the range of 10–17 MtCO2/yr (yellow dot; Fig. 2b). This measurement, from a tectonically active area as small as 45.000 km2, corresponds alone to about 2.7–5.6% of the global Earth's emission budget of 367 MtCO2/yr recently assumed as reference value (IPCC, 2013).
Results reported here show that global estimates of the Earth's CO2 degassing are inconsistent with both, point-source volcanic emissions and diffuse soil degassing measured in the last 20 years, highlighting major limitations in current measurement approach. The absence of a reliable understanding of the processes in the crust and in the mantle leading to variable enrichment of CO2 in magmas makes point-source extrapolations non-representative, mainly preventing a direct evaluation of the (volcanic and soil) Earth's emission budget. Volcanic degassing at the Earth's surface constitutes only a part of the total CO2 released by magmas. Those non-erupting magmas, or stoping at some km's depth, can degas unconsidered CO2 fluxes in the crust, potentially of the same order of magnitude or greater than those directly measured on the volcanic structures at the surface. In addition, it seems evident that current extrapolations from diffuse degassing measurements are
only at their infancy, since the number and nature of potential sources are not fully explored.
Conversely, data analysis shows that the mechanisms of Earth CO2 degassing are well described by the presently considered Earth's geodynamic models (i.e., plate tectonics). These outstanding results show that an accurate estimate of Earth's degassing budget requires the evaluation of deep CO2 fluxes (i.e., long term Earth's carbon cycle) through the mantle and the crust (e.g., Dasgupta and Hirschmann, 2010; Manning, 2013). On this line, mass balancing of volcanic and non-volcanic degassing measurements with crust and mantle CO2 fluxes based on petrological models, indicates an amount of natural CO2 degassing in Italy up to 5–8% with respect to the anthropogenic one (Frezzotti et al., 2009). While this regional example is not conclusive to a global scale, the well constrained measurement strategy in Italy (e.g., Chiodini et al., 2008) balanced by petrological modeling suggests natural emissions of an order of magnitude which goes well over the highest average estimate for the natural Earth's CO2 degassing, and constitute a good example of the potential applications of petrological models to the estimate of the global Earth's CO2 emission budget.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text:
Analysis of results published in literature shows inconsistencies between estimates, global extrapolations and measurements leading to the evidence that the Earth's CO2 natural emission budget, independently from its absolute value, is virtually unknown. This leads to important uncertainties on the evaluation of anthropogenic perturbations of key climate processes and then on the quantification and prediction of climate issues and remediation scenarios. Results show a constant increase of the global extrapolations of the natural emissions with the number of measurements, from 0.3 to 2.6% of the anthropogenic CO2 in about 20 years (1991–2013). Un-recognized carbon processes at depth and fluctuations of the CO2 emission rates at the surface bias the estimates and the statistical extrapolations of the measurements to a global Earth's CO2 degassing, and cast doubt on their representativeness with respect to the actual Earth's emission budget.
The effects of an under-determined value of the CO2 Earth's emissions, with a distinctive C isotopic ratio, raise several problematic questions about the understanding of the physical and geological processes governing the global carbon cycle.
In a recent paper, Shepherd (2014) extensively reports on errors related to climate prediction scenarios arising from uncertainties in non-linear dynamics, and on needs for a better characterization of the physical mechanisms behind climate variability. Beside model uncertainties and stabilization scenarios, an unknown value of the natural Earth's emissions leads to inadequate parameterization of unsettled pivotal processes relevant to studies of the global carbon cycle, atmospheric processes, ocean and land uptake, air–sea exchanges, and mantle petrology and dynamics.
On this line, a second paper from Regnier et al. (2013), underlines the importance of anthropogenic perturbation on the carbon fluxes along the land-ocean aquatic continuum. Authors' extensive report on the mechanisms of carbon cycle highlights the effects of uncertainties of the natural degassing on the Carbon Cycle. A careful analysis of data shows evidence of large error ranges on the value of geological fluxes. In term of fluxes, this unconstrained geological value, with a distinctive isotopic signature, could greatly bias the estimate of post-industrial ocean and land sinks, and the global carbon cycle.
